Former Denver Nuggets executive Carl Scheer waves to fans as he is honored before the start of an NBA basketball game in Denver in 2014. Scheer ran both the Nuggets and the Charlotte Hornets during his career, and both those teams have honored him. Scheer, 82, lives in Charlotte and has dementia.

Former Charlotte Hornets General Manager Carl Scheer, left, and team owner George Shinn answer questions in 1990. Scheer wanted a guaranteed contract to stay in Charlotte. Shinn refused to give it to him, which led to Scheer’s departure. The two men eventually made up.

NBA legend and North Carolina basketball hero Michael Jordan scored 33 points in a Dec. 23, 1988 game against the Charlotte Hornets, his first game back in his home state. The Hornets ultimately beat Jordan’s Chicago Bulls 103-101 on a buzzer-beater, starting Charlotte’s 364-game consecutive sellout streak.

N.C. State’s David Thompson soars to the basket against Virginia in the 1974 ACC tournament. As Denver Nuggets general manager, Carl Scheer was able to lure Thompson to the ABA rather than the rival NBA.
Carl Scheer and his wife, Marsha (left), have been married for 59 years. They met as counselors in a summer camp.

Bob Scheer is the son of former basketball executive Carl Scheer, who has dementia. “I was his son, and then I became his business partner, and now his caregiver,” Bob Scheer said. “So it’s sort of a full-circle thing.”

NC State’s David Thompson (left) shoots over North Carolina’s Bobby Jones in 1974. Carl Scheer would employ both men with the Denver Nuggets. He would later say trading away Jones was one of the worst personnel moves he ever made.

Former Charlotte Hornets shooting guard Dell Curry was selected in the expansion draft by Carl Scheer. “I will forever be indebted to Carl for bringing me here,” said Curry, who retired as Charlotte’s all-time leading scorer. “Obviously, it changed my life.”
The first edition of the 1988-89 Charlotte Hornets lost 62 of 82 games, but the team entranced the city under general manager Carl Scheer (seated, fourth from left).
During the 1988-89 NBA season, Charlotte Hornets general manager Carl Scheer (left) and team owner George Shinn had lots to smile about as their team began a streak of 364 straight sellouts.

Leslie Williams, a school bus driver for Charlotte-Mecklenburg Schools, lives in a Habitat house in Seversville in the Johnson C. Smith University area. Her tax value jumped a 188 percent increase from its 2011 value. “Over time, this neighborhood has gotten better, and I’m glad for that,” she said. “I just hate the fact that it’s gotten better but now I can’t afford to live in it.”

Dale Earnhardt Sr. (left) and Gordon formed a fierce rivalry during the 1990’s, before Earnhardt’s tragic death in 2001.
Gordon won his first Cup championship in 1995 at the age of 24, making him the youngest series winner in history.
Gordon’s 93rd and final NASCAR Cup Series win, at Martinsville Speedway in November 2015.
Gordon celebrating his third Cup Series championship in 1998 after winning the ACDelco 400 at Rockingham Speedway.

Gordon (right) earned Hendrick Motorsports owner Rick Hendrick (left) his first Cup Series championship in 1995, and the two are now business partners at the team.
The first of Gordon’s 93 Cup Series wins came in the 1994 Coca-Cola 600 at Charlotte Motor Speedway.
Gordon (24) has two children, Leo (left) and Ella Sofia (right), with his longtime wife Ingrid Vandebosch.

Former NASCAR driver Jeff Gordon, right, smiles for photographers with his wife, Ingrid Vandebosch, left, and children, Leo and Ella Sofia at the NASCAR Hall of Fame Class of 2019 induction on Friday. Gordon headlined a magical class.

The Concealed Carry Reciprocity Act of 2017 would require any state that issues permits for carrying concealed weapons to recognize concealed-carry permits issued by other states -- even if those states have different eligibility and training requirements and less stringent restrictions on gun ownership.

On Feb. 12, 1960, 41 students from Shaw University and St. Augustine’s College were arrested on trespassing charges at Cameron Village in Raleigh after refusing a request to leave by an official with the shopping center. The students had earlier staged a sit-in at the F.W. Woolworth lunch counter at Cameron Village. George Greene, left, a Raleigh lawyer, met with some of the arrested students at the Wake County jail. The protest was among a wave of demonstrations that followed a lunch counter sit-in on Feb. 1, 1960, by four N.C. A&T State University students at Woolworth in Greensboro.
